snippet.textDisplay:
Did you notice if Dragon Quest VIII is based on Knight & Baby/Guardian's Crusade for its game world environment?

For anyone don't know about Knight & Baby/Guardian's Crusade:
Knight & Baby, or called "Guardian's Crusade" in US version, is a PS1 JRPG that its world isn't symbolized with icons or 3D icons for any places in world map such as towns, dungeon entrances, house, etc like traditional JRPG. Instead, all of them are directly rendered. So, you can see any details of any towns without entering it. 

Proofs if DQVIII is based on Knight & Baby/Guardian's Crusade are:
-Anything at world map is completely not symbolized by any icons.
-Music changes if you enter the town, except for loading screen and people appears after loading screen. K&B/GC have no loading screen when entering any towns and any people at any towns are visible even the town isn't entered.
-You can only land at outside of any towns, except for auto landing positioning when you want to land at inside of any towns.
-Visible enemies, only for 3DS version of DQVIII.
-Ship can only parked at specified place. For DQVIII, you can only park ship at the port.

snippet.textDisplay: I have an interesting love-hate relationship with this game. I love the beautiful cel-shaded graphics, I love the characters, I love the British voice acting and the world as a whole. But in this game the random encounters annoy me way more than in any other RPG. The dungeons and the distances in the world map are so long that you are going to hear that same battle theme loop over and over and over again. Not to mention that you can only save in towns, so if you die, you go all the way back. This is possibly the single hardest J-RPG I've ever played and not for the right reason. I still love this game, but I've never finished this and having spent over 100 hours with this, I have decided not to come back and finish this at any time.
snippet.textOriginal: I have an interesting love-hate relationship with this game. I love the beautiful cel-shaded graphics, I love the characters, I love the British voice acting and the world as a whole. But in this game the random encounters annoy me way more than in any other RPG. The dungeons and the distances in the world map are so long that you are going to hear that same battle theme loop over and over and over again. Not to mention that you can only save in towns, so if you die, you go all the way back. This is possibly the single hardest J-RPG I've ever played and not for the right reason. I still love this game, but I've never finished this and having spent over 100 hours with this, I have decided not to come back and finish this at any time.

@Nifty That would be exactly what I said, yes. The Roman system goes, at specific intervals, an I is placed before a multiple of five to denote being less than that interval of 5.

I = 1

II = 2

III = 3

IV = 4

V = 5

VIII = 8

X = 10

IX = 9

snippet.textDisplay:
I don't know why it matters that I mentioned Mozart, it should be obvious what point I was trying to make, so i find it unnecessary to get so hung up over that.
Most people would interpret my comment as "oh, he thinks this sounds like something that might have come from artists like Mozart, and that it has the same kind of classical feel as the music from his time period".

You still gave the wtong impression and i'm uncertain you know enough about musical composition to tell such.
"Just because Mozart had a certain style it doesn't mean he would not be able to use other styles"
It actually does. The style you have as a composer isn't defined by the genre, is defined by personal traits and preferences. Let alone Mozart had such musical inequiparable talent due him being autist, and that I find Uematsu kinda overrated(not saying bad, but overrated).

snippet.textDisplay:
I didn't say this sounded exactly the same as Mozart's own works, I said it sounded like something he would have been capable of writing and that it held the same level of quality as his own works.
Just because Mozart had a certain style it doesn't mean he would not be able to use other styles - look at Nobuo Uematsu for example, I consider him just as talented as Mozart and he has written all kinds of songs for the Final Fantasy series, even though he gravitates towards classical music.

snippet.textDisplay: @MyHumanLife (continued). As much as I love modern RPG's, and as much that I love that they've diversified and have developed deep stories and different types of settings, going back and playing DQ8 makes me remember why I fell in love with RPG's in the first place. It's just a simple fantasy setting, yourself as the hero, out to save the day from a bad guy, with fantastic music and stylized graphics. No complicated moral issues or demigods or "grittiness", just straight-forward, rpg goodness =)

As much as I love modern RPG's, and as much that I love that they've diversified and have developed deep stories and different types of settings, going back and playing DQ8 makes me remember why I fell in love with RPG's in the first place. It's just a simple fantasy setting, yourself as the hero, out to save the day from a bad guy, with fantastic music and stylized graphics. No complicated moral issues or demigods or "grittiness", just straight-forward, rpg goodness =)

snippet.textDisplay: I adore Dragon Quest VIII. There are lots and lots of great RPG's out there, but one of the things that makes me love DQ8 so much is its simplicity. Not that it's easy, but it isn't overcomplicated in the story or in the game's mechanic's, it's very straight forward. This gives it a nice nostalgic feeling to it, especially if you grew up playing 16-bit era rpgs. It gives me the same "feeling" games like FFIV and Lufia gave me back in the day. And the music is amazing ;)
